I don't disagree with this. But the issue is, what do you mean by "accept?" Do you mean 'agree to disagree'? That I can continue feeling that homosexual behavior is wrong but accept you no less? (If that's your view of acceptance, I can do that.) But if you view of acceptance is for people to give up their religious views altogether about what is acceptable behavior and what is not, and basically say "it's ok to do that" , then no. I know you probably hate the phrase "love/accept the sinner, hate the sin," but like it or not, it's a valid way of viewing gay people (and people in general).

 
 In a sense, tolerance is both of those things. Someone who "agrees to disagree" with another but accepts that person no less is more tolerant than someone who does not do this (though I should point out that giving heterosexual couples the benefits of marriage while denying these benefits to same-sex couples indicates a lack of acceptance, not acceptance. Denying rights to those who do not meet one's own opinion of what is the right way to live removes accpetance of that lifestyle from the law.) Someone who changes his or her religious viewpoints to validate this lifestyle could be considered even more tolerant, though I don't think that this much tolerance is necessary to call oneself a good person.
 
 Also, I do agree that it is both valid and morally good to love the sinner, not the sin. I will argue, though, that it is morally wrong to consider something a sin which harms no one and helps many (though I suppose it could be called "valid" to do so), even if one's religious belief commands it. Religious beliefs will never be an acceptable excuse to harm people, by denying them rights or otherwise.
 
 
I think you'd be hardpressed to prove these two assertions. But FWIW, I agree with you that NO one should have violence perpetrated against them. And NO one (gay or anyone else) should be discriminated against in the workplace or in home buying.

 
 Would I be hardpressed? I don't have any statistics here, but I have heard these statistics presented to me at some point. But even without statistics at hand, I'm certain you will agree that same-sex relationships are looked down upon by incredibly large numbers of Americans, and it would only make sense for them to be discriminated against more than other groups because of this.
 
 
You seem to be implying that people are less tolerant toward gay people than they are people over issues of race. My response to that is, you should try to tell that to the family of the late James Byrd in Texas.

 
 This is what I am implying, and I would state it again, even to the family of James Byrd in Texas. I do not doubt that there is racial intolerance in our country; I don't doubt that at all. But I do doubt that more people are racially intolerant than they are intolerant of sexual orientation. When television shows preach racial equality, the community applauds. When television shows preach equality of sexual orientation, many people scoff and speak out. Perhaps this is a better indication of the state of our tolerance than any reasoning I can provide.
 
 I should also mention that just as James Byrd was murdered because of his race, there have been countless people murdered because of their sexual orientation. Those people deserve mention here as well.
 
 
And in many ways, public sentiment IS what determines what tolerance is. But I would definitely agree that we should all be intolerant of violence against any individuals or group of people.

 
 Well, you're right; public sentiment does determine what tolerance is, but I don't think it does that in the way you are implying. As the public becomes more tolerant toward a group of people, being "tolerant" applies less to people who the community already accepts and more to people who are not accepted. For example, I would probably not be justifed in calling myself a "preacher of tolerance" because I speak of equality for people with blonde hair, even though my hair is brown. Society already accepts blonde-haired people as equals; preaching equality toward them means nothing. Only by supporting people who face the most intolerance can I say that I am truly preaching tolerance. If I simply spout out what the community already agrees with, then I'm pandering to the beliefs of society and pointing myself in the direction we are already headed; I'm not addressing the real intolerance.
 
 But you have said that you oppose violence toward any individuals or groups of people. If this is the case; I do not see why you should have any problem with the creators of SpongeBob SquarePants preaching for tolerance. Increasing tolerance of homosexuals and bisexuals will decrease violence against them. I think we can both agree that this is a good thing.
